content: whose dmg welcome to the dmg info where we're going to be sponging and dry
bashing wargaming ultra cheap seats about to rain
all right so if you're enjoying these
videos consider supporting me by purchasing products on my store the dmg
info forward slash store and every little piece helps to bring this content
to you in the format that you're seeing it in or in the future of
holographically so sponging and dry rushing so we're going to grab a sponge
but this time we want to get one that looks a little bit like Swiss cheese
little holes and things in it if you don't have one get a normal sponge and
you can probably use something hot like it the soldering iron to make the holes
so anyway cut a decent sized square probably one and a half inches by one
and a half inches and then round it off so we're going to make the whole thing
round so you just make sure the top of it is round just trim off any excess
sharp bits because we don't want any sharp edges when we're using the sponge
so that's why we do that so we're now we're going to grab a green and a yellow
again this is all from video one the colors that we have in our limited color
palette put down a big blob of green and a big blob of yellow mix them in but
don't mix them in thoroughly so that you can still see bits of yellow and bits of
green and then we're going to sponge it on lightly
so this is going to create a bit of a fractal pattern on the pizza box wargame
terrain board which we have obviously pv8 covered in sand and now we are using
this sponging technique and so continue to go over with the sponge we're using
boots of speed obviously that's why this is accelerated and begin to blend the
edges between the browns and the Greens don't go overboard with the blending and
just moving to one of the other tiles here you can see that the tiles are a
little bit patchy because of the different techniques I was using this
one obviously I did not allow the PVA to dry before I under coated it and I was
doing that for a specific effect so again we're just sponging on the green
and yellow you think it's starting to really
bring out the green in this piece and you still got a little mottled effect of
the variation and you continue to sponge it so that you get it to the gradient
that you prefer so we just moved again to another tile this one's the river one
and again just stamping pay particular attention to the edges so you want to
keep the edges quite uniform and so make sure that you hit the edges quite a lot
and then again we're just blending the edges of the weather Brown is into the
grass itself so then we're going to move straight along and we're going to grab
another circle one or you can wash the previous one with a big dollop of brown
paint and start to do all the brown areas and again begin to blend in the
green with the brown so that we're getting a sort of a nice blend effect
there and continue to cover over all the stones and things like that and here at
the base of the front here you can see I'm pushing quite hard just to get that
Brown right into the corners so you can depends on the sort of piece that you
have as to how you're going to use the sponge to do the painting so there's
sort of what it looks like at the moment a bit of mud flow and that nice sort of
blend between the top and the bottom there so let's move on right along and
now we're gonna do the riverbed we're just going to use again Brown just to
hit the riverbed there and again re blending the edges of the side of the
river and hitting some of the rocks there as well and what you can also do
is a little bit of brown in the green areas just where there'd be a variation
in color so you can use it just a sort of like a maybe a dyeing patch of grass
or a little bit of mud showing through or something to that effect then in the
pond one we're going to again apply to the base of the pond and all around the
edges and again in the hole and over all the stones with this brown paint so once
you've done that grab a big dollop of white and a half a dollop of black
mix them together with your sponge again you can just continue to use the same
sponge you head with a brown on that's fine it doesn't matter if it has the
brown in it and we're just going to lightly sponge on the top of all little
stones that are not going to be underwater so just sponge on the top of
the stones that aren't going to be underwater until you have a lot less of
the paint on it and then you can just dab slightly where there is going to be
water so anywhere where the rocks are raised above ground again we're just
sponging it on there and you can also use a little technique here where you
roll the sponge you just roll the edge of it to get into those little tight
places so now we're going to start dry brushing so if you were to dry brushes
with a small brush if it would take four times longer then if we just use a
massive wide brush now that's why brush cost me about a dollar at the dollar
store so it's not expensive to get one of these if you're going to do a lot of
this type of terrain it's a worthwhile investment so we can use a dot straight
yellow now you load up the brush and then you brush off as much as you can
onto a paper towel or in this case I had in that paper towel so I'm using some
bog roll and then you're going to dust over the whole piece with that yellow
now this yellow I started with is a water very watery yellow so it's not
hitting the piece as well as I would like so I went down a board another
yellow and we're going to begin to use that and you'll start to see the
difference here as that yellow is applied so this is really warming up the
greens now you might ask well why would you want to do this well if there's a
lot of sunlight you're going to have much warmer tones in your terrain so you
don't have to do this tip if you want if you want to use different color or a
lighter green etc you can do this it's just what's nice with the yellow is it
blends with the brown as well so blends quite nicely so even if you hit the
stones and things like that it's warming up the whole piece so that's why I
prefer to use yellow in these and again we're just going to go over the whole
piece and this is the pawned piece and we're going to go full on Brutus period
get this yellow all over the shows you can see it's really starting to warm up
the whole lot and then we're going to load up some yellow and do the pond base
as well so the pond base just not going to brush off too much of the yellow
paint just brush it straight into the base and into the hole as well so that's
what it looks like then has broader bright out so that sponging and dry
brushing thank you for joining me if you like this video you like and of course
check me out on Facebook and Twitter and of course my other channel 7d system
where we talk about all things role-playing games and other interesting
stuff that's just not technically terrain don't know why I'm doing this
maybe it's because I left my tripod in the car
